text: 17 this evening, Exodus chapter 17. And if you were with us this morning, I kind of gave a segue at the end of the message into the message this evening. It's not really a part one, part two, but it serves as and certainly could be a part one, part two. Of course, as we look at Exodus 17, we've skipped a few events that have taken place since the event that we looked at this morning in Exodus chapter number 14. But this morning we were challenged by the instruction that God provided to his servant Moses to deliver to the children of Israel. And that instruction was found in Exodus 14 and verse number 15. When the Lord said unto Moses, wherefore cryest thou unto me, speak unto the children of Israel that they go forward. And we dealt with the truth of the importance of going forward. We asked four questions this morning as we looked at that passage of scripture. We asked this question, why do we go forward? Well, we go forward as a matter of obedience because the Lord has instructed us to go forward. How do we go forward? We go forward by faith. The just shall live by faith and we believe that God is able to do what God said he would do. We then asked this question, what hinders us from going forward? We know that we've been instructed to go forward and we know how we're to go forward. But the reality is that there are times in our lives, no doubt, even as the children of Israel would experience in events that would take place in their history, where we are hindered from going forward, the doubts and the fears and the obstacles and the influence. And we looked at those things. And then we asked the final question this morning, what happens when we go forward? And very simply, we get to see the Lord work. And what a blessing to see God work, to see God do what only God can do. And the children of Israel, they went forward and they got to see God perform miraculous work in dividing the Red Sea and keeping the Red Sea parted and of course, overthrowing the enemy. And they rejoiced greatly in the 15th chapter of the book of Exodus. In fact, the Bible begins in the 15th chapter and it says, they sang, then sang Moses and the children of Israel, this song unto the Lord. And Spake saying, I will sing unto the Lord for he hath triumphed gloriously. The horse and his rider hath he thrown into the sea. The Lord is my strength and my song and he has become my salvation. He is my God and I will prepare him in habitation. My Father's God and I will exalt him. And we find that as you go through the 15th chapter, they're singing and they're triumphing and verse 21, it says that Miriam answered them, sing ye to the Lord for he hath triumphed gloriously. The horse and his rider hath he thrown into the sea. And I mean, they're rejoicing and we get to see God work. And we said this, that our faith too would be increased. I mentioned this morning at the close of the service that oftentimes our faith is increased through times of difficulty, through obstacles. And we find that it's in those times in which our faith is often increased. There are really the misunderstanding that many have that is if we follow God, if we are obedient to God, if we're living by faith, if we go forward as we've been instructed to do so, then we'll have no problems. There'll be no difficulties. There'll be no obstacles, no opposition. Everything will be just perfect. It's not that way. Come to the end of the 15th chapter, as I mentioned this morning, and the Bible tells us that they found no water and then they went a little further and they went to Marah and the waters there were bitter and they could not drink those waters. The first obstacle that the children of Israel faced after they went forward, after they obeyed the Lord, after in obedience and by faith, they did what God told them to do. They were not hindered. They went forward and they found themselves facing this obstacle. The reality is that when we face obstacles in life, we must understand really two things before we get to the 17th chapter. I would say this, the obstacles that the children of Israel faced and the obstacles that we face are known by God. They're known ahead of time by God. And I would say this, He has a purpose for them. God was the one that led the children of Israel out of Egypt land. In the Old Testament, in this particular era, we find that the nation of Israel, they were led by a pillar of cloud by day and a pillar of fire by night. And we find that as God would provide them with leadership, even as we sang the song this evening, follow on, follow on, and we find that they would follow God, that there were times in which as they followed God, He led them directly into a time of testing, a time of faith building. We find that these obstacles in which we deal with, the obstacles in which the children of Israel would face, these obstacles, we must understand and recognize that they're known by God and that they have a purpose. They have a purpose. Let me say this, obstacles are not designed to detour us or to derail us. Rather, obstacles are to grow us. They're to grow us. And we find that the children of Israel, they face this obstacle at the end of chapter 15. We mentioned about the manna this morning in chapter number 16, and you understand what happens there. And we come to the 17th chapter, after they had gone through and they've understood this, the provision of God through the manna, they've seen God heal the waters there at Marah. We find that the Bible tells us in chapter number 17, beginning in verse number one, and all the congregation of the children of Israel journeyed from the wilderness of sin after their journeys, according to the commandment of the Lord and pitched in Rephidim, and there was no water for the people to drink. If you're taking notes this evening, I've simply entitled the message, Pitched in Rephidim. They pitched in Rephidim. And that's the place where we find in verse number one, the Bible tells us the place in which they would set up camp. They pitched in Rephidim. Now I want you to understand that as we look at this passage, and we'll look at the first seven verses of Exodus chapter number 17, I want you to understand number one, the circumstances that are provided. God provides us with some circumstances right away in verse number one, and as we look at these circumstances, we find that it's interesting to know that the Bible tells us that the congregation of the children of Israel journeyed from the wilderness of sin after their journeys. Notice this next phrase right in the middle of verse number one, according to the commandment of the Lord. I want you to understand that it was not Moses that just all of a sudden decided, we're going to pick up camp and we're going to move. It was not that they were following the leadership of Moses exclusively. No, it was not the idea of some group of people, some group that came up with this idea and this committee decided that we're going to move forward and we're going to go over here and we're going to relocate. No, the Bible tells us that they went according to the commandment of the Lord. According to the commandment of the Lord. They were obedient. They were, as we mentioned in chapter number 14, that command of go forward, and now we find that they're going and they're obeying, they're following the leadership of God, and the Bible tells us at the end of verse number one that they went according to the commandment of the Lord and pitched in Rephidim, and it says this, and there was no water for the people to drink. Now this is a problem. The congregation of the children of Israel is a large congregation. It's not a small group of people, as I mentioned this morning. It's not just a handful of people that were crossing that Red Sea. Really the estimates that are given are nearly two million people that would have crossed over and that are being, of course, traveling at this point. He created us, right? God knows that we need water. He knows that it is a basic necessity for mankind, for human beings to survive. It is necessary that we have water. You can live longer without food than you can live without water. It is a scientific, medical-proven fact. We need water. In fact, there are times in which we understand, as we've lived and as we've experienced life at certain levels and doing various activities, that there are times in which we can become dehydrated. I'm not sure about you, but I know of me. If I'm doing something and I get to the place where I become dehydrated or even on the edge of becoming dehydrated, I can feel that I need water. I love sweet tea. But there are times that I just need water. God knows that we need water. That everything's just going to be perfect. Well, they're in this place according to the commandment of the Lord, and there's no water. God knows that they need water. I want you to notice not only the circumstances, but notice number two, if you're taking notes, the complaint of the people. In verses 2 and 3, we read of the complaint, the murmuring of the people of Israel. It's one thing that they were consistently good at was complaining. Not much has changed in thousands of years of human history, for the reality is that it's very easy for us as human beings to complain about our circumstances. It's very easy for us to look at the negative aspect of the circumstances in which we deal with, and thus I believe it's so often throughout the Word of God that we are given the instruction to rejoice evermore, to be thankful, to give thanks in all things, because the reality is that it is easy to complain. In verses 2 and 3, God records for us the complaint of the people. Notice in verse number 2, the Bible says, wherefore the people did chide with Moses. That word chide is an interesting word. It means to contend or to argue with. And look at what they said, give us water that we may drink. Can you imagine? Can you imagine being Moses and having this large group of people nearly two million in size, and you follow the direction of God, you're in the place where God has led you to be, and you're there and there's no water, and the people now come and they're contending, they're chiding with you, they're arguing with you, and they say, give us water that we may drink. And Moses said unto them, why chide ye with me? Wherefore do ye tempt the Lord? The people thirsted there for water. The Bible says in verse number 3, and the people murmured against Moses. To murmur means to grumble or to complain. They're complaining about their circumstances. They said this at the end of verse number 3, wherefore is this, that thou hast brought us up out of Egypt to kill us and our children and our cattle with thirst. Man, aren't they so negative? Isn't it easy for us when we face adversity, when we face obstacles, when we face these types of circumstances to just become super negative? Think about all that they had experienced. Think about all that they've witnessed and they've seen the hand of God. Think about the message that I preached this morning about the crossing of the Red Sea and the miraculous power of God that was displayed that these people saw firsthand. Think about the time after crossing the Red Sea or at the place of Marah and there's bitter waters and God heals the waters and they're able to drink. And think about the manna that they had had to eat for breakfast that day, to have as nourishment for that day. They'd seen God work. But they're thirsty. And they chide. And they murmur. They were disappointed with their circumstances. And I would say this, their prior experience had not built their faith. I wish I could read Exodus 17 and I understand that often as we look back, even in our own lives, but especially in the lives of others, that it's very easy for us to say, man, if they would have done this or if they would have done that and we can do that in our own lives and we can look back at circumstances. They say that hindsight is 20-20 and obviously when we look back and we say, man, if I would have just trusted here, if I would have had this perspective. But wouldn't it have been interesting if we could read Exodus 17 and read of the people how that they just kind of got together and said, I wonder how God's going to work in this situation. I mean, do you remember what God did just a few days ago when we crossed over the Red Sea? Do you remember how God blessed and how he worked and provided that water? He healed those bitter waters. Do you remember that manna that we've been enjoying? I mean, what is God going to do? How is God going to work? And how is God going to provide? What is God going to do and have some measure of excitement and anticipation and expectation of seeing God work? Unfortunately, we don't read it that way. Because You've commanded us to, it's a matter of obedience. Help us to go forward in faith. Help us to see You work as only You can. We pray that in these few moments of invitation that You'd have Your will in way, that Your Spirit would move in the hearts of those that are gathered locally and those that have tuned in on this service tonight. That, God, we'd be doers of the Word and not hearers only. Well, thank You for the work that You'll do. For it's in Christ's name we pray.

segments.text: 17 this evening, Exodus chapter 17.

into the message this evening.

one, part two.
Of course, as we look at Exodus 17, we've skipped a few events that have taken place
since the event that we looked at this morning in Exodus chapter number 14.
But this morning we were challenged by the instruction that God provided to his servant
Moses to deliver to the children of Israel.
And that instruction was found in Exodus 14 and verse number 15.
When the Lord said unto Moses, wherefore cryest thou unto me, speak unto the children of Israel
that they go forward.
And we dealt with the truth of the importance of going forward.
We asked four questions this morning as we looked at that passage of scripture.
We asked this question, why do we go forward?
Well, we go forward as a matter of obedience because the Lord has instructed us to go forward.
How do we go forward?
We go forward by faith.
The just shall live by faith and we believe that God is able to do what God said he would
do.
We then asked this question, what hinders us from going forward?
We know that we've been instructed to go forward and we know how we're to go forward.
But the reality is that there are times in our lives, no doubt, even as the children
of Israel would experience in events that would take place in their history, where we
are hindered from going forward, the doubts and the fears and the obstacles and the influence.
And we looked at those things.
And then we asked the final question this morning, what happens when we go forward?
